text:
When I saw this recipe's ingredients, I wondered what the fuss was about. Today, as I eat yesterday's wilted leftovers from a Tupperware container at 9am in the morning, I thought I'd write a review! I make this salad all the time now. I use spinach and other greens. I use toasted (10 minutes in 350 oven - no butter) pine nuts now insead of the almonds and will never go back - they are perfect for this salad. I add one container of blue cheese (a must for us - perfect blend of flavors). I use one 6 oz package Craisins. I've never used the poppy seeds - but the toasted sesame seeds (also at 350 for 10 minutes) are a must. I may or may not use dried minced onion.  Toss all dressing ingredients in a container with a lid - and shake! This salad has been a hit with everyone I've served it to - dinner party, Easter lunch, dinner at home. It is so easy and easy to transport, too - just add the dressing once you get to where you're going. Try it - I bet you'll love it!!

WOW! AWESOME! TIME saver tips: use Paul Newman's balsamic vinagrette instead of making your own dressing. MONEY saving tip: use "Craisins" dried cranberry fruit instead of regular dried cranberries.  Use can of mandarin oranges instead of poppy seeds. THIS WAS A HIT!

text:
I'm sure this salad was delicious, but I couldn't bring myself to make it as published, instead dressing it with something far less sweet.  Since the sugar content isn't part of the nutritional info, you might find it enlightening to know that it contains a whopping 174 g (that's a full cup's worth) of sugar, or 2T per serving, assuming you used sweetened dried cranberries. If you managed to find unsweetened cranberries, you can reduce that figure to a "mere" 96 grams. Having as much or more sugar than your average cupcake qualifies it as more of a dessert. Because salads are typically thought of as healthy, you should know what your'e getting into with this one! Rating is for recipe as published, not with adjustments.

text:
I have made this about 4 times.  Each and every time, someone asks for the recipe.  This is a delicious and especially pretty at Christmas time with the green leafy spinach and red dried cranberries. Dried cranberries are very expensive when purchased in the grocery store.  Buying a large quantity at Costco, Sams Club, etc saves money on this item; and the cranberries keep for so long on the shelf. Easy to make!  Toasting the almonds is crucial for flavor  - don't miss that step.

text:
This salad really is as great as everyone says, although I used a different dressing...  Try pureeing a cup of raspberries (frozen ones are fine!) with a tablespoon of sugar, 1/2 cup of peanut oil, a teaspoon of poppy seeds, and 3 tablespoons of balsamic vinegar for a light, fruity dressing.  I also substituted walnuts for the almonds and added a good bit of feta cheese.  (I never can stick to a recipe-- I can't help but personalize!)  Overall, this is a GOOD salad!

text:
HELPFUL TIP REGARDING DRESSING: I love this salad & salad dressing.  The longer it marinates, the better it tastes.  Problem is, the dressing doesn't last long, & we never use even half of it since it's only a family of 4.  So, I make this salad using a dressing I found from another spinach cranberry recipe on here that has a 5* rating.  I keep it in a lock n lock, & it's good for weeks (esp if you're like me & use milk that doesn't expire until a month later)!  Mix 1/2C mayo, 2T white WINE vinegar, 1/4C milk, and before you serve your salad ...add sesame seeds and/or poppy seeds.  It's delicious & no one can taste the mayo, & they SWEAR it's better than any ranch! Very gourmet AND don't be afraid of the mayo ...it calls for that much b/c it makes almost a bottle size amount (that again stays good forever).  To the salad, I like adding fresh sliced strawberries, dried blueberries OR mandarin oranges with the cranberries. Also adding a sprinkle of sunflower seeds gives it a nice crunch!  I sprinkle some almond accents on as well (seasoned almonds found next to salad bags).  Perfect with any meal and always a hit!

text:
O.K one more person to rave about this salad.  Next time I will use one half the oil and sub olive oil for the vegetable oil.  I used roasted, salted pecans, toasted the sesame seeds and used bagged spinach (cut down on time).  You could cut down on the sugar also as the cranberries add the sweetness.  Be sure to use a pound of spinach or you will have plenty of dressing left over.  Diabetics could use sevin or splenda in the place of sugar.  Beautiful, attractive salad used a cobalt blue bowl for a bold presentation.

text:
This is the recipe that got me hooked on allrecipes. I have made it for years now, and have tried an infinite variety of versions. 

I settled on adding chicken, sesame oil, mandarin oranges, and skipping the poppy seeds. Don't worry, I'm rating the original recipe, not my modifications. It is all good, both the original and just about any substitutions that you care to make, including lettuce for spinach (if you have to).

The dressing is key, just keep the 1:1:1 ratio of sugar, oil, and vinegar and you can't go wrong.

text:
I just finished my 3rd bowl of this salad! I am supposed to take this to a baby shower tomorrow, I hope I have enough!!It is so good, just as everyone else has said! I followed the recipe pretty closely, except for reducing the amount of white sugar as others have recommended, the dressing is delicious! I also added dried raspberries (I had them in the cupboard) and sliced red onion. Instead of using butter, I dry toasted the almonds in the oven. I did use the sesame seeds & poppy seeds (you may not be able to taste the poppy seeds, but I love the look of them in the dressing!) I bagged the almonds, craisens, and red onion in ziplocs, put the spinich in a huge bowl, the dressing in a jar & I plan on assembling this salad at the shower so it does not wilt. This is one of the best salads I've had in a long time, I can't wait to have people over to make it again!

I have gotten more compliments on this salad then anything I've ever made! The flavors are just wonderful, and the buttered almonds with dried cranberries definately makes the salad. I leave out the onions in the dressing, and use red wine vinegar instead of white.  I also don't put the sesame seeds and poppy seeds in the dressing because they always stick to the dressing container and I lose half of them. I just sprinkle them on the salad now.  I will be making this many, many, many more times!!! :)

city:

country:

text:
I have been making something similar for about 20 years, but I use fresh strawberries instead of craisins and I do not put poppy seeds in the dressing!  DO NOT cheat yourself out of experiencing the fabulous dressing...it's what makes the salad and is far superior to anything store bought!  I make mine in the food processor and add the toasted seasame seeds to the spinach, strawberries & almonds in the bowl, not to the dressing.  Pulse the vinegar, sugar, onion, and paprika a few times to combine. Flip the switch to "on" and drizzle the oil through the hopper on top of the food processor. This emulsifies the dressing and gives it a bit of a "creamy" look.  I use canola oil instead of veg. oil and also like to add a little bit of white pepper.  This salad is an all time favorite and great for special occasions. Everyone loves it and you will get MANY recipie requests!  Enjoy!  :-)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This salad is absolutely yummy, although I did make a few changes.  I found the dressing a little on the sweet side, so I decreased the sugar by 1/4 c.  I also decreased the vinegar a little and only used white wine vinegar because that's what I had on hand.  I used white onion, but I think red would give it a bit more color and taste great too.  Now for the goodies... I added about 1 1/2 c sliced fresh organic strawberries (this was the best thing ever), and also some cooked crumbled bacon and cubed avocado.  Instead of cooking the almonds in butter, I just spread them on a baking sheet and baked them dry at 400 degrees for 5-8 min, watching to make sure they didn't burn.  This helps reduce some of the fat, and they still tasted great.  I cooled the almonds a little before adding them so that they wouldn't make the spinach wilt.  Next time I'll also add some crumbled ramen noodles, because I love all the crunchies.  All in all, this was a terrific recipe!  If you were to add anything, I would highly recommend the strawberries - they were awesome.  Thanks, Jamie!

text:
I brought this to a Labor Day Weekend BBQ and everybody (about 12 people) raved about the salad.  Not one leaf of spinach was left in the bowl!  

I did make some adjustments to the recipe:  Added about a tablespoon of worchestershire sauce for an added kick and toasted the sesame seeds before adding them to the dressing for a nuttier flavor. Didn't have poppy seeds on hand, so I left them out.  Finally, I used fresh sliced strawberries instead of the cranberries (mostly because they were in season and very inexpensive).  The dressing was delicious, but I was careful to add it  to taste.  Even though we served this salad to 12 people, we had quite a bit of leftover dressing which I plan on using again tonight.

I will definitely make this recipe again and will try it with the dried cranberries when strawberries aren't in season.  Very tasty and a great change from a standard green or spinach salad.  Yum!

city:

country:
None
text:
Loved it!  Took it to our Thanksgiving dinner this year and my father wanted the recipe as soon as possible. That told me how great it was.  I made it exactly as directed except for toasting the sesame seeds in the oven (350 degrees/10 minutes) and also toasted the sliced almonds in the oven the same temp/time. I mentioned that he could add mandarin oranges, or feta cheese, or pine nuts, etc.  This is one recipe you can truly be creative with and not go wrong. One thing I won't do next time is toss the baby spinach, toasted nuts, and dried cranberries the evening before (I had to travel and made everything the night before).  The next day, the spinach was not as fresh as it could have been if I would have just left it in it's original container.  I would recommend not doing a "fix ahead" in this manner.  I did make up the dressing the evening before and it fit nicely in a pint canning jar.  So, if you are traveling with this salad, keep each item in it's original packaging until you arrive at your destination and then toss it all together.  Hope this helps others!

I loved this salad!  I did add blue cheese crumbles in it the second time I made it and now I don't think it's complete without it, it was a perfect compliment to the flavors. The dressing was super yummy, and it got great reviews at both parties I brought it to. I reduced the sugar the first time I made it, and then did the full amount the second time.  I prefer it with the full amount, I didn't think it was too sweet, it was perfect. text:
Updated: After many (many) times making this, I'm convinced it doesn't matter what add-ins you use as long as you stick with the dressing as listed (oil, both vinegars, sugar, minced onion, and paprika) and the craisins. Personal preference: mixed baby greens, craisins, sunflower kernals, cheese (bleu if I plan enough in advance, cheddar or colby jack if I'm just using what I have in the fridge), and diced grilled chicken (pounded flat and marinated in Yoshida's sweet and savory glaze). I've been eating this for lunch almost every day for the last month and I still can't get enough. I just keep a batch of dressing pre-made in the fridge at all times and can throw together an individual bowl when I want.

text:
This salad is amazing! I made it this Thanksgiving and all of my family loved it and asked for the recipe! I did follow one of the reviews and used pine nuts (toasted) in place of almonds. Everyone really enjoyed it. I used spinach that you can buy in a bag that is already washed and cut and made the dressing and toasted the pine nuts the night before. I placed the cranberries and nuts in separate ziploc bags, had the dressing in a plasic drizzle bottle (not sure what the exact name of those are, I bought them at Michaels by the candy making products), and had my bag of spinach. I brought it all to the dinner and threw it together in about 1 minute. Talk about easy. I did find that the recipe for the dressing can be used for two bags of pre-washed, pre-cut spinach.

I've made this salad several times and have emailed the link to the recipe several dozen times. If you put Newman's Own on it, then it's Newman's salad, not Jamie's.  Huge difference.

text:
I made this for a dinner gathering and it all went quickly!  This recipe is a keeper for sure.
I used butter lettuce which was good, but too bulky.  Next time I will use a blend with spinach. 
Also... it is very important to add the dressing just before serving.  I jumped the gun and tossed it in 30 minutes prior to serving and it condensed to 1/2 the size.
Half of the sugar was MORE than plenty.  I also used sweetened dried cranberries.  I wouldn't be able to eat it if it were any sweeter - and I love sweet.
Almonds were toasted dry and I used extra virgin olive oil instead of veg oil.  Glad I did!
Thanks for the recipe!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
My go-to salad whenever I have a crowd to wow. I find the dressing to be a LOT. The dressing makes the spinach pretty soggy, so pour on very little at a time, mix in well and stop when it looks okay coated, you can always offer your guests extra dressing. I skip the poppy seeds, toast either sliced almonds or pine nuts (whatever I have on hand), and if I can I like to do some nice goat's cheese and canned mandarin oranges... yum! 
Make sure to toss the dressing in very slowly first, then throw all the goodies on top or else they all fall to the bottom~ enjoy!

userID:
1867459
Display Name:
Kym Cox Surridge
isPro:

53

457

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2810793.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I eat salad every day, and I have so many great recipes, so it takes a lot to impress me--and this one did. What an excellent combination of flavors! The dressing didn't taste all that special on its own, but once it was tossed with the salad...delicious! I made several minor modifications, all based on personal preference: I don't like raw onion, so I used shallot because it's milder; I used 1/4 cup agave nectar, which is the equivalent of 1/3 cup sugar; I toasted only half of the nuts and seeds (in a dry skillet) because I like the flavor of them raw as well; I used pumpkin seeds instead of poppy seeds because that's what I had on hand (although now that I know I'll make this salad often, I'll buy poppy seeds); and I used olive oil instead of veg. Plus, I used home-dried cranberries, which were more tart. The texture of the spinach was just perfect for this salad--I wouldn't make it with any other green. Thanks for a great new salad recipe to add to my ever-expanding collection!

text:
I loved this salad - great combination of flavours. A couple of suggestions though: definitely 1/3 cup sugar is enough. Also, you don't need butter to toast the almond - do it in the oven or a dry pan on the stove - they're much less greasy. Finally, although I really liked this dressing, I can see how some might find it too vinegary - I might try it with a little less vinegar and more oil next time. But truly, the taste is excellent and worth making!

Delicious!! I used balsamic vinegar instead of apple cider vinegar. I also used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. We all enjoyed the nutty flavor the toasted seasame seeds added..do not skip that step, it's vital! Also I reduced the sugar to 1/4 cup as other reviewers did, it was plenty sweet enough. The almonds were pefect in flavor and texture. I think 1 cup of cranberries is too much, so next time I will reduce it to 3/4 cup. Everyone loved this salad and the dressing was wonderful.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely fabulous for the holidays!  I toasted both sesame and poppy seeds just a little in a heavy skillet.  Poppy seed flavor comes out nicely when you toast.  I did reduce the sugar just a bit and I used fine granulated sugar for baking instead - it blends much better.  Also, try using a cheese grater to grate your onion into a wire strainer.  You'll get lots of juice, but the onion takes on a wonderful flavor and not strong and too crunchy for those who are not overly crazy for onion.  I love them, but grating the onion makes for a milder flavor and serves to enhance the taste overall.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Unusual, and it tastes fantastic! My new favourite salad. I did not include the poppy seeds and it still tasted good. I did use more sesame seeds than suggested. Oh, and I cut the sugar to half or even less as the cranberries are very sweet in themselves. Put the greens in individual salad bowls, top with toasted nuts and cranberries, then pour the dressing on top for your guests to toss themselves. That makes for a pretty presentation and avoids the problem of the "bits" falling to the bottom of the bowl and getting lost.

text:
Took this to work for food day and everyone loved it, especially the dressing.  I made it according to the recipe, using organic baby spinach (didn't chop it up) and substituting extra virgin olive oil for the vegetable oil.  It was easy to make the dressing the night before, toast the almonds and put in a baggy after they cooled, then combine the spinach, almonds and dried cranberries right before lunch, shake up the dressing and toss everything together!

text:
LOVE this! I've tried various substitions (pine nuts vs almonds, using different dressings for a short cut) but the original recipe is my favorite. The dressing is one of the best I've ever made - the sesame seeds and poppy seeds add so much flavor. Definitely toast the almonds in the butter, it adds a very special touch. The only variation is I always use a nice extra virgin olive oil (NOT vegetable oil as the recipe says). Last night I also added goat cheese for the first time and I loved it and will include that moving forward. Every party/dinner I serve it at every last drop is gone (and everyone asks for the recipe).

text:
I decided to try this recipe because of the thousands of great reviews. I followed the recipe exactly. I split it into two bowls, one I added almonds and the other I put in pine nuts as recommended by other reviewers. It turned out too sweet that I had to get rid of the excess dressing and diluted the remaining with water and kept draining it. I added black pepper, some lemon tuna slices, all in one packet spices and salt. And even after all this, my family and I think its one of the worst salads we ever tried.
If you still want to go ahead and try it, I suggest NOT putting a half cup of sugar, other reviewers added 1 table spoon and were happy with the salad, so don't put too much, taste it and then decided if you want to put more.

BEST SALAD EVER!!!
I usually don't like salads that are potentially sweet, so I was hesitant when making this. I was SO happy with the results. It wasnt too sweet; as a matter of fact, it was sweet and salty. This is a recipe that I will make again and again! I am making it for dinner tonight and I am going to add some chopped apple and a bit of shredded cheese.
YUM!!!

text:
This is incredible, mostly because of the dressing. It is nutty and rich from the toasted sesame seeds, sweet with the sugar, and just the right amount of balanced tang with the vinegars. I made in a small tupperware container, so I could keep shaking throughout the night for my dinner party of 4. I didn't have cranberries (oops), so I used chopped up dried apricots, which worked quite nicely. Thanks for this awesome and relatively cheap alternative to store bought dressings!

text:
I made this for a lunch yesterday. I didn't want to add the poppy seeds since so many reviewers said it wasn't necessary. However, I did toast the almonds AND the sesame seeds. The salad dressing smelled too vinegar-y it was a turn-off at first and I was worried no one would like it. But I mixed it in with the salad anyway and it wasn't so bad. The ladies at the lunch complimented on the salad - they really liked it! :) The host emptied my salad bowl and kept the rest (which wasn't much anyway). Overall, this was great.

text:
This salad is incredible!  I could eat it daily and my whole family loves it.  I didn't add the sesame or poppy seeds b/c they were a tad expensive for the small amount I was going to use.  I sliced some red onion into the salad instead of adding it to the dressing and I also added bleu cheese as suggested.  I love mixed greens and the dressing + blend of flavors was amazing!  The only downside is that the salad wilts quickly so leftovers are a little sad looking.  We usually just keep the ingredients on hand and add the dressing individually instead of tossing the whole salad - problem solved!  SO GOOD!

text:
When I first made this, I wasn't quite sure about it; but in retrospect, i believe the flavors are simply so stunning you have to be careful what you eat it with.  In otherwords, as a side dish at a BBQ, not so impressive;  As a main course by itself or with a very mild flavored meat such as chicken or fish, this works well.  Made as directed with only change being the addition of about a 1/4 cup of dried cherries as I ran out of dried cranberries and having to use smoked almonds (which I think really enhanced the flavors and balanced out the sweetness of the dressing).  Will make again :)

text:
This spinach salad is even better than the SEVEN SPINACH SALAD, also offered here - and the difference is the toasted almond slivers.  Toasting the almonds makes all the difference, as it brings out the flavor soooo much more than just serving them raw.  Be careful not to burn these - it's easy to do.  These salads are just wonderful.  The combination of flavors is what makes them so outstanding.  In this recipe, it's the complementary flavors of cranberries, toasted almonds and spinach.  I threw in a little mixed salad greens - about a cup - with baby spinach leaves.  The dressing pulls it all together.  This salad is killer.  I feel healthier already!

Jamie's recipe is wonderful!  I've been making a similar recipe for years.  Some fun alternations we have done are using cashews instead of almonds, using black sesame seeds instead of poppy seeds/sesame seeds.  Just use what you like! text:
I really enjoyed this recipe.  I have eaten one very similar that had apples, cheese chunks and cashews.  The dressing was also similiar except instead of the paprika it had dried mustard powder.   

I followed the recipe for the dressing except that I substituted olive oil for the vegetable oil. The dressing was a little strong in the vinegar flavor and sweetness.  I think next time I'll reduce the sugar and increase the olive oil.

I liked it so much that I wanted to finish off my bag of spinach so I used some extra dried cranberries(from the bag I bought) and added sunflower seeds because I ran out of the almonds.

I have found myself thinking about this recipe several times since I made it and I'm eager to make it again.

This is definitely a keeper!!!

text:
This recipe truly is fantastic. I adapted it a little based on other reviews and my personal preferences. I used brown sugar instead of white, and a little less sugar than the recipe called for. I was short of white vinegar, so I added a little lime juice. I used pine nuts instead of almonds and left out the poppy seeds. I also used Craisins. People LOVED it. I'm going to take this to my next potluck this Sunday. The dressing does make much more than you need, so I have enough left over for this Sunday that I don't have to make any more. This recipe is definitely a keeper.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this salad for years and people literally lick their plates. Throw ingredients in order into a mini food processor (pulsing as you go along) to whip up the dressing.  By using only apple cider vinegar and leaving out the white wine vinegar, you can reduce the sugar to between 1/4 and 1/3 cup.  I add sliced fresh strawberries instead of cranberries, as well as cubed avocado and mango, and a can of drained, mandarin orange pieces.  I also often substitute 2 bags of assorted greens for the spinach. If toasting almonds, not necessary to add butter to pan, just brown in non-stick pan and the natural oil in the nuts will do the job.  One word comes to mind when thinking of this recipe - divine!

text:
Yummy!  We omitted poppy seeds ($$$) and halved the oil-- I might even decrease the oil next time.  This makes enough dressing for twice as much salad as is listed-- we ended up mixing in a romaine blend to try to use it all.  We served the almonds and cranberries on the side to keep them from sinking to the bottom of the bowl.  We also added bleu cheese crumbles-- wouldn't be nearly as good without them.  All that said, I ate it four meals in a row (yes, breakfast included)-- and I usually hate leftovers!  Definitely a keeper!

country:

text:
Well, nobody "raved" about this.  In fact, out of 10 dinner guests, no one even commented on it, but it was well eaten.  I thought it was good but I have had better salads, so this fell short of a 5 star.  I would not make this again simply because there are better ones out there.  If you plan to try this, one suggestion I would strongly make is not to toast the slivered almonds in butter.  Once they cooled and were on the cold salad, they were greasy because the butter had solidified.  If I were going to make this salad again, I would definitely toast the almonds the dry method way.

text:
Excellent and so easy! I used mixed baby greens and added a little crumbled feta because that's what I had in the fridge (but goat cheese or gorgonzola would also be great), and I loved the extra flavor, texture, and visual appeal brought by the cheese. Note to those who thought this was too sweet: Don't just dump on ALL of the dressing at once-toss the salad as you gradually add dressing, just enough to lightly coat the greens.  This recipe is a wonderful blend of flavors and textures, and I love that this salad looks impressive while being so easy!

text:
I made this exactly as the recipe said and it was WONDERFUL. The fact that I was eating healthy spinach even made it more appealing. It will be hard to go back to lettuce salads. 
I'm going to have to agree with Jteam here as well. Rate the recipe on its own merit, that way we get a true rating. Love all the other suggestions, but yes, post it as a separate recipe,  that we can also try it and rate your version of it.
NEXT DAY: 
I had to come back and add this to my review. After dinner, I had just about 1 1/2 servings left. I was interested in seeing how the salad would hold up for left overs. Especially since the salad was already dressed. So I got rid of the dressing that was at the bottom of the serving bowl and put the salad in the fridge. The next day I had it and the spinach had taken on a different texture and so had the flavor. The salad had more depth to it. With the changed texture and deeper flavor, it was like a whole different salad.  The first time around it was bright, the second time around it was still good. I shall be absolutely making this salad again as is and definitely saving the leftovers.

You could play around with this, but it's perfect as is. I did reduce the sugar just a bit (for a double recipe, I used 3/4 cup). I also eliminated the butter and just cooked the almonds in a nonstick skillet without it, and I used sunflower oil instead of vegetable oil. All very minor tweaks. Took it to a potluck and had several requests for the recipe. I would highly recommend it!

Awesome salad!  A couple of comments: Make sure you separate the dried cranberries from each other, as they often are clumped together out of the package. text:
This salad is outrageously good.  I used regular mixed greens instead of spinach, because that's what we had on hand, and it was great.  I sprinkled candied nuts over top and that really set it off!  (See Bea's recipe for "Pecan Snack").  Be aware that the vinaigrette for this recipe is very sweet.  I happen to love it, but somebody who doesn't love sweet dressings may be put off.

userID:
6471863
Display Name:
velvetmonster

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I toast the sesame seeds in a dry, non-stick skillet until they are golden, grate the onion, use dry-roasted almonds, and skip the sugar/vinegar combo and just use balsamic vinegar. Usually I make a half batch, but even then, reduce the amount of balsamic vinegar to 1/3 cup. Also, I prefer olive oil to vegetable oil. I've used Romaine for this, also. Almost as yummy, but not quite. I also have substituted raisins for the cranberries, it's OK, but not as good, and nice for a change if you basically start eating this salad every single night like I have.  

So good I really have trouble eating salad any other way.

I have made this salad twice and both times it was delicious with a very unique flavour for a spinach salad. I aboslutely loved it!
I made a couple of changes: I halved the sugar and oil, and used raspberry vinegar instead of cider vinegar. I think the sesame and poppy seeds are key so do not leave those out. I'll be making this many many more times! Thanks Jamie!

text:
This salad was very good.  But I made the mistake of listening to one of the other viewers & used "Newman's Balsamic vinegar".  All tho I love balsamic vinegar, this DID NOT go good with this salad.  Next time I will make the original dressing.  Always try the recipe as is, if it's not to your liking, then try something else.  I did not have wine vinegar, so thought balsamic dressing would do.  I will make this again, and know it will be a lot better with the dressing that is written down.  Learned a lesson

text:
Very good salad, but I prefer to use pecans instead of almonds.  I saute them in butter, then add brown sugar and let them cook a couple of minutes, cool, then break apart the sugar/pecan candy.  I also like dried cherries rather than cranberries.  Always loved at dinner parties.

This salad is absolutely delicious! I made the dressing exactly as written, but used a spinach and mesclun mix for the greens.  The mesclun lent the salad a bite of bitter spiciness, which went incredibly well with the dressing. I topped it with walnuts, cranberries, and blue cheese. This is my favorite salad to date! Thanks Jamie!

Delicious! At first I was skeptical to try this recipe  as my husband is somewhat picky about salads, preferring  the basic typical house salad with ranch dressing. I made the salad, and ended up serving it the next day (wasn't planned that way) never the less it was absolutely amazing. Such a nice change, and everyone who has tasted this when I make it loves it. My husband commented this was the best salad he has ever had. I now make the dressing a day or two before hand, not sure if it matters but it tasted amazing and I don't want to change a thing.

text:
This is my favorite salad recipe. I make it for my family several times a month. It's magnificent as-is but I make the following changes to suit our preferences...I add bacon bits, blue or gorgonzola cheese, roasted pine nuts instead of almonds (I don't measure any amounts of any of these, I just throw it in and stir it up until it looks like a good ratio of goodies to spinach) I reduce the oil by 1/3 and use olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  Thanx Jamie!  I will never look for another spinach salad recipe!

text:
This is an excellent salad that can be used year around with whatever fruit/nut you have available.  I recently tried fresh orange segments and toasted pecans - absolutely delicious! Other variations that have won my family over are: banana & pistachios/banana & almond/fresh peaches & almonds/apples & walnuts/pineapple & walnuts with toasted coconut.  I always add a few extra nuts!  I also use stevia in place of the sugar in the dressing.  This salad fits most any diet. The dressing makes the salad.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Have made this three times. It is a great salad, both refreshing and filling at the same time.  Twice now I have used a "shortcut" where I toast the almonds and the sesame seeds at the same time in the same pan with the tablespoon of butter (watch carefully, it goes fast and could burn easily). Then I pour a half cup of Cranberry Walnut or Raspberry Walnut ready made (Like Paul Newman's brand) salad dressing in a bowl, dump in the almond/sesame seed mixture and stir and then pour on the spinach and top with the cranberries. Very fast and easy.

text:
This truly is a great recipe...I know it off by heart I've made it so many times.  TIPS:  I agree with the other users that toasting the almonds is a MUST.  I'm indifferent with toasting the sesame seeds -- sometimes I do, sometimes I don't.  Also, I never add the sugar...instead I always dice up an apple (choose a sweet variety like GALA or FUJI).  I've also added a pear instead of an apple and still was a great salad!  Thanks for this recipe -- always a hit at my dinner parties..

text:
Made it exactly as stated, except added blue cheese as suggested - it goes perfectly with this salad.  Do NOT omit toasting sesame seeds, it gives it a little Asian flair and it changes the whole taste without it.  The dressing keeps well in refrigerator. If you keep the salad items on hand, it's easy to pull out and make a quick salad.  I ate it five days in a row for lunch and still am not tired of it!  Thanks for my new favorite salad recipe!

I absolutely LOVE this recipe. This is my go-to recipe for salads- everyone always requests it!! I do alter it a bit: add blue cheese crumbles, mandarin oranges, craisins. I also toast the sesame seeds and almonds together in the oven until browned. I add onion powder in place of the minced onion (I actually prefer it taste and texture-wise better) And I use a mixture of red leaf lettuce, green leaf lettuce, and spinach. SOOOO yummy!!!!!!

text:
Made this earlier this week.  I don't eat a lot of meat and my daughter is a vegetarian.  The problem we have in our house is I have two big meat eaters, my wife and my son.  Trying to make meals that satisfy everyone can be difficult.  This is one of the few that did.  I added Turkey Bacon for them and also Blue Cheese crumbles.  As a main course I think at the least you should add Blue Cheese and maybe even red onions.  I also did substitute Pine Nuts for the almonds and it was excellent.  The only reason I did not rate higher was it would have been a bit bland without these additions.  I also put some cold mandarine oranges at the table for those that wanted them.  Honestly, you could even add some of some of those crunchy chinese noodles for texture if you are omitting any meat.

text:
WOW!  I loved this and so did everyone who had it at a big group dinner I just had.  I followed the recipe as written except I chose to use a mixture of spinach and mixed greens and added in some crumbled gorgonzola cheese and it was a really nice compliment to the other flavors.  I toasted the almonds in the oven for a nice crunchy texture.  The dressing is fantastic.  I used more than 1 lb. of greens and this was plenty of dressing for it.  I made the dressing ahead of the party and kept in in the fridge in a small tupperware bowl.  When I was ready to serve I shook it up and tossed it with the salad.  Can't wait to make this one again.

COOKINGDABBLE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674135.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was an extremely delicious salad! I rinsed and drained store bagged baby spinach for quick salad making, dumped in dried cranberries, sprinkled feta cheese, used 1/4 cup olive oil instead of veggie oil, forgot the onion (but will use thin slices of raw red onion next time, and omitted the poppy seeds (didn't have any).  The dressing was very quick to make but found the sesame seeds did not survive being in the vinegrette for more than 3 days - so keep them separate until just before serving if you have left over dressing to store in your fridge! The toasted almonds were delicious, and a wonderful flavor to the salad.  I used "I can't believe it's not butter" instead of real butter to toast the almonds, as that was all I had, and didn't notice the difference. I also lightly dry  toasted the sesame seeds in a pan - it made the flavor pop! will definately make it again, and will add different things such as mandarin oranges or sliced strawberries, or use thinnly sliced parmesan or asiago cheese instead of feta next time!

text:
This salad is SO popular!  Everyone I made it for absolutely loved it.  I did a couple of things differently from the recipe.  Instead of dried cranberries I used fresh strawberries that I quartered.  I also roasted the almonds in the oven without the extra butter at 350 degrees for 8 minutes stirring them after 4 minutes.  I toasted the sesame seeds in a 350 degree oven for 8 minutes, stirring them after 4 minutes.  It's easy to make the dressing in advance and just toss right before serving.  I don't even like spinach salad, but I liked this.  It's great for a crowd.  When I had to take a salad to a Passover seder last year this is what I made.  Everyone LOVED it.  In fact, it was specifically requested again this year.  It's really easy to multiply too.

text:
I wanted to like this recipe, I really did.  The first taste of it I thought "Wow!" because the poppy seeds and sesame seeds gave it a real kick of flavor.  But after a few bites the dressing was hurting my tongue because it was a bit too sweet and a bit too tart all at the same time.
The next day the spinach was soaked and even more unpleasantly too sweet and tart.

I made another batch a day later to bring to a party and followed the recipe amounts carefully. I figured maybe other will like it even if I don't.  Same thing for me.  Too sweet and too tart.  Hurt the roof of my mouth.  There was alot of good food at the party so the salad had tough competition.  It was only half eaten and I threw the rest out.

Not likely to make this dressing again.  A sprinkling of olive oil, sesame oil and sweetented rice wine vinegar does the same for me.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-01-02T06:59:21.513
helpfulCount:
3
userID:
11028683
Display Name:
winelight
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
35
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3648295.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was on salad duty for a NYE party and knew that for the crowd I'd be serving, romaine with a few tomatoes and some ranch dressing wouldn't fly. So I found this recipe and gave it a shot. After reading the majority of reviews, I decided that I'd reduce the sugar to 1/3 cup. I omitted the poppy seeds as I don't like them and toasted the sesame seeds and then the almonds in a dry pan. Dry toasting gives nuts & seeds incredible flavor, but be careful not to burn them or they'll turn bitter. I used just over a cup of Craisins and pre-packaged salad in a variety of types - mixed greens and lettuces. I pre-made the dressing sans oil, packed everything separately and just put it together at the party and dressed the salad there. I was really nervous as this was a blind recipe I'd never tried before. Personally, I found it much too sweet for my taste, but everyone LOVED it! It was almost entirely gone.
Be sure to state to everyone you're serving that there are almonds in the salad. I had two guests that were allergic to walnuts but almonds turned out to be fine. It was something I just hadn't considered, so definitely be aware. Anyone can throw a salad together with a bottled dressing. But people obviously really like this salad WITH the dressing recipe given, so I'd recommend people try making the dressing.
Oh, and dress the salad initially using 3/4 of the dressing. Using the whole amount seemed like way too much and it wilts fast.

I usually don't review recipes, but this one was fabulous!!!  Didn't have time to toast the almonds, but I'm sure that would make this salad that much better. Another positive response to the salad.  I (of course) made a few small adjustments.  With baby spinach, there was no need to rip or tear pieces, which I liked. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is great! It's really simple and sophisticated. I found it too sweet though, so next time I will halve the amount of sugar. To make it vegan, instead of using butter to toast the almonds I used Burgundy cooking wine. It have a nice depth to the almonds. I used white vinegar, but I'm not sure if its white wine vinegar. I used a red onion for the onion, since it is more tangy and less bitter when uncooked. I used extra virgin olive oil instead of vegetable oil to make it healthier, and while the olive oil flavor doesn't always work I found it did very well here! I will definitely make this recipe again! Thank you.

text:
I took this to a get-together where it got great reviews - and NO leftovers!  I tossed the cranberries and almonds prior to adding the dressing but they all sunk to the bottom, so I redid it and layered the spinach, almonds & cranberies in a 9x12 glass pan and sprinkled with some gargonzola for color.  I substituted Splenda/sugar blend for the sugar.  Poured the dressing on just before serving.  I will definately make this again!

text:
This is delicious! I wanted to make it into a very healthy, full meal. To that end I used agave nectar instead of sugar and only used 1/4 c. I also added 2 c. cooked quinoa and 12 oz. cooked chicken breast. I dry roasted the almonds and sesame seeds. Used 1/2 t. onion powder instead of minced onion. Finally, I had no white wine vinegar so I used white balsamic instead.  FANTASTIC!! This was a very filling meal (when I ate 2 portions!).

text:
Excellent salad and dressing. The salad itself was very simple; nothing terribly unique about it. But the dressing! Oh my, the dressing! Really, really good! For the salad, I used Spring Mix rather than just spinach. And for the dried cranberries, I substituted a mix of dried cherries, cranberries, and raisins instead. That's all I had. And instead of the almonds, I used pumpkin seeds that were dried and then sauteed in seasoned butter. Used olive oil in the dressing instead of just canola or vegetable oil. The dressing was so flavorful, not too sweet, and really just perfect. This one's a keeper.

I JUST made this and OMG, it was fantastic.  My changes were as follows: I didn't use almonds or toast any, I used pecan pieces.  Cut down the sugar to 1tbsp (there's enuf sugar in the cranberries), and also cut the vegetable oil to 1/8 cup.   I also used dried onion (2tsp) instead of fresh.    At the end, I added crumbled Goat cheese, as I have to have cheese in EVERYTHING.  It turned out amazing. This is definitely a keeper of a recipe, and I promise you won't be able to put the bowl down to write the review.  I wasn't even out of the kitchen yet and I finished the salad.   THANK YOU!

None
text:
Oh my word. This is so good. I know it doesn't need a five star review, but I just had to write one anyway. It's very versatile - instead of almonds, I've used sunflower seeds, cashew pieces,and pecans (not all at once!). I've used raisins instead of cranberries. I've added mandarin oranges. But it's the dressing that really carries this one over the top. I use 1/2 c red wine vinegar and no cider vinegar, and Splenda instead of sugar. It's absolutely perfect. I mix up a whole recipe, but don't use the dressing until I'm ready to serve it. It holds up very well in the fridge for about 3 days this way, and I've been known to eat it for breakfast. 5 stars, at least.

I sort of made-do with what I had to make this for dh's work lunch. I dry roasted pine nuts (all I had) and only used poppy seeds as I ran out of sesame. I also added some full fat Danish feta (yum!) and chopped, poached chicken breast. I used a packet mix of baby spinach and rocket and because this is a very green salad, I asked him later what he thought of it. He said it was really great and the dressing worked well. 4 1/2 - 5 *. So, I'll give it a 5. This salad is going to be easy peasy to give him as dried cranberries don't really go bad, nor seeds, nor nuts and just add a bit of cheese and meat and I'm good to go.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this twice--once for my family and once for co-workers. It went over extremely well both times. This is a GREAT salad! I read through previous reviews to see what other people added or changed, and based on the reviews I made some changes myself. I omitted the poppyseeds (only because I didn't have them), added mandarin oranges, and added some feta cheese. I used Craisins for the cranberries. I didn't use the butter on the almonds--I just toasted them in the oven at 350 degrees for about 10 minutes. I added some garlic powder to dressing, and I grated the onion instead of mincing it. It's also important to let the salad sit for 20 minutes or so with the dressing on it before serving. This salad looks pretty on the plate with all of the colors, and it is SO good. I can't get enough of it! I didn't realize how much I could like spinach!

text:
Try adding a thinly sliced slightly tart apple for added crunch.  Also, for a slightly different take, I'll substitute pomegranate seeds instead of cranberries.   Have found that filling a mixing bowl about halfway with water and separating the pomegranate seeds from the skin in that helps to keep the bright red juice from splattering!  Enjoy!

country:

text:
My husband and I LOVED this!!  I have to admit I sometimes overlook the recipes that have tons and tons of reviews.  I finally tried this one because I had some spinach to use up and I had all the ingredients.  I was sorry I hadn't tried this recipe sooner!  I tried it a week ago and have made it three times this week.  And I usually don't repeat recipes.  I didn't toast the sesame seeds, but did toast the almonds.  I also used red wine vinegar instead of cider.  Then I ran out of red wine so the next time I used balsamic, and that was great too.  I also use a red onion for the onion, which added great bits of color.  The salad is great as-is, but I added crumbled gorgonzola to my plate and shredded parm to my husband's.  That just took it over the top!  I find myself wanting this salad often.  Now I always have the ingredients on hand to whip it up.  Oh, I cut the sugar in half.  I think it would be way too much otherwise.  I also use a good-quality olive oil.

An AMAZING salad! I was so pleased it came out perfect. I pan roasted almonds AND walnuts and then salted them. Let them cool then added to salad. Also I know some people don't want to make the dressing but it was really great and better than any you could buy. It took no time at all. I added green onions to the salad because I did not have onion seasoning. Also I only used 1/3 cup of sugar as the salad with cranberries was sweet enough. I suggest less sugar and MAKE the dressing yourself! PERFECT!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this several times and it is always a hit.  In the summer, I substitute a 15oz. can of garbanzo beans and a pint of grape, or cherry, tomatoes for the cranberries.  The dressing needs to be modified to make up for the absence of the fruit sugar within the berries.  
   I found that changing it to 3/4 cup sugar and adding 1/3 cup ketchup keeps the flavor similar.  I have also used fructose sugar instead of white cane sugar; when doing this cut the amount in half.  In this recipe I only needed to use 1/3 cup plus a TBSP of fructose sugar to equal the 3/4 cup of cane sugar.  The sweet taste is the same with fewer carbohydrates and calories.

text:
I followed this receipe very closely.  Both my husband and me thought the vinegar overwhelmed the taste of everything else and made the salad to sweet overall. Next time I make this I will find a ligter oil to add more of and reduce the vinegar by about 75%.  Otherwise, this actually was a tasty salad and I hardly even realised I was eating spinach-a plus in my book!  If you plan to keep this over one day, keep the spinach and cranberry mix separated from the dressing.  I think this could be a great way to get kids to eat their spinach (kids like me)!  There is anothr salad recipe on this website called strawberry and spinach that I plan to try and post a review of soon.

This is an amazing salad if you don't skip the important steps of making the dressing yourself and roasting the almonds.  What I mean by that is don't shortcut it and buy dressing from the store.  What I did was make 2-3 servings of the dressing and keep it in the fridge for whenever I make this salad.  Also, when adding onion I only use purple onion and I also add blue cheese which adds so much to the salad. Great recipe!!

text:
Really good, and easily modified to your tastes.  I made the dressing almost as listed (just use virgin olive oil, halfed the sugar and added a little artificial to it).  I thought it needed a little more of something, so added about 2 teaspoons of Raspberry Vinagrette dressing that I had on hand.  I chose to omit the cranberries (lots of calories there) and used a can of mandarin oranges and added 3 boiled chopped eggs.  I thought my picky husband would turn it down, but he loved it.  It was a meal for me and I think you could add almost any mix of veggies you like.  I only dinged it one star because the dressing needed a little more flavor.

text:
I have made this so many times it has become my "PLEASE MAKE YOUR SALAD"..for all events. A couple of suggestions:
Make dressing in advance, I add in the almonds and cranberries in the salad dressing ................. additionally Spinach wilts very quickly, so if you are having a buffet type of meal you may consider putting out the spinach and the salad dressing in a cruet separate. Important also I double the recipe and keep it for weeks. I also cut the sugar in half.........

caraszone

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4027008.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent as written, a wonderful spinach salad.  I used baby spinach, it is easy to work with and tastes great.  You can buy sesame seeds already toasted.  I used shelled almonds rather than slivered for a heartier crunch and toasted them the same way.  I did toast more than I needed the first time and I found I could freeze the leftovers.  It made it so much easier the next time I wanted to make a simple side dish with dinner or light lunch.  I didn't have to take all that extra time to toast the almonds again.  When making the dressing I minced fresh onions not dried.  With a spinach salad dressing poppy seeds are a must, I would not eliminate them if at all possible.  I have refrigerated this dressing and used it all week without effecting it's flavor.

Display Name:
Kay

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is excellent!! I only have a couple of things that i want to add.  First is that the finished product doesn't look to appetizing, probably because the yellowish color of the oil is too prominent.  Adding some diced up cranberries and letting stand for a couple of hours will add some nice coloring to the mixture.  Using red onions in place of the plain will have the same effect.  Secondly, instead of toasting the almond with butter, toasting them in the toaster oven for 5 minutes will give it that toasty flavor minus the grease.  I used left over pecans from the pecan pie and it blended well with the dressing.  The amount of sugar can be adjusted, too, to the level of sweetness desired.  This recipe is a hit every time!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked this. I used the calculate button and changed it to 2 servings and still got 3 descent sized servings for lunch to try this. I followed the recipe ingredients, exactly, except I cut the amount of cranberries by half. It was a good amount. I also just chopped up some whole almonds well, and toasted those as directed. This is probably not something I would make for a week night dinner, but I am going to keep it in mind for a holiday. If making for a buffet or holiday, make sure to add the dressing only right before serving. The dressing some what quickly breaks down the spinach. It is best with the spinach still crispy. I think, for a party, it would be well received though.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My kids even liked this salad but I made it a little different.  I like really quick recipes so I made adjustments to make it as easy as possible.  I used Spinach, Craisins, Oven Roasted chopped Almonds, Pine nuts, tri-colored Tortilla strips (in the salad isle by the croutons) and bought Kraft Balsamic Vinagrette dressing (16 oz) and added some Splenda packets (to make it a little sweeter) in the bottle and shook .  I let everyone make their own salad in a bowl and put the toppings listed on for themselves.  My son doesn't like Craisins so he just used the nuts and tortilla strips.  Just pour the salad dressing on top the salad instead of mixing all together because if you don't eat all the salad that night it will be mush by the next day.  I also bought a Roasted Chicken at the Grocery store when I got these ingredients so supper was ready in about 5 minutes.

Ive made it for nearly every fall/winter holiday meal Im involved in and it is consistently a reliable way to WOW folks. text:
This was really good. When I was mixing the dressing, it tasted too vinegary and I was a little worried but once mixed with the spinach, the flavor is wonderful. I used a bag of dried cranberries and cherries. The only thing I left out were the poppy seeds cause I couldn't find any in the grocery. I served the dressing on the side and we drizzled as much as we wanted. My picky health conscious husband loved it and asked if I could add walnuts next time.

Don't drown the salad in dressing, as the taste of vinegar could be overwhelming... Just add enough to coat the spinach. Thanks for this great recipe.. Ill be making it regularly.

text:
This recipe is great I have been making it for years now. I've used regular white vinegar instead of rice vinegar when I'm out and that taste really good too. It is on the sweeter side but I think that is what makes it special. I omit the onion. I do not use butter to brown my almonds, I just do it stove top on a pan and do the same for the sesame seeds. My kids and hubby love this salad and I try to make it once a week. I find that when I halve the recipe it taste less sweet, not sure why but still delish.

text:
I couldn't believe all the rave reviews this recipe got, because tihere are hardly any ingredients in it.  But boy was everyone right!!!  THis salad is absolutely delicious.  I made it for the first time Christmas day, and my family LOVED it.  I used toasted walnuts instead of almonds because it is what I had on hand.  I also attempted to half the sugar, but everyone agreed it needed the full amount to balance the vinegars.  The salad doesn't require a lot of dressing, so don't worry about the sugar!   My husband, who isn't so crazy about salad, has asked me to make this several times now.  Try it!!!  You won't be sorry!!!!  :)

Display Name:
WREDWRUM

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Because this recipe had so many reviews...I just had to try it! I read as many of the 5-star reviews and suggestions as I could, and then quite a few of the ones where people said they didn't like it. It seemed to me that the main reason people didn't like it was because the dressing was too overpowering. I took a lot of the suggestions of other reviewers and altered the recipe only slightly, and it was -- as so many others have already said -- fantastic! I used a 1/4 c Spenda, dry roasted the almonds, used mixed greens in addition to spinach, did not use poppy seeds, used Craisins and a small can of Mandarin oranges, only used 1/4 c olive oil and sprinkled reduced-fat feta on top afterward. (I also added cucumbers cut into quarters because my boyfriend loves them.) I did not add the dressing directly to the salad but drizzled it on prior to eating just in case it was too much. It was extremely tasty and my boyfriend raved about it and said this should be something we make all of the time. This one is a keeper!

text:
This was a hit! It's perfect for eating dinner outside on warm nights. I made the dressing as directed (love it!) but adapted the salad slightly. Like a few others, I toasted the almonds in the oven for about 10 minutes at 350. I didn't use the poppy seeds or sesame seeds. I bought Craisins because they cost less, and I also added mandarin oranges. Crumbly cheese like feta, gorgonzola or goat cheese work wonderfully for added flavor!

text:
This is fantastic. Really, really great and so incredibly easy.

Someone suggested simply using Paul Newman's vinegarette?? That's insane. The combination of the vinegar and oil in this recipe is wonderful.

I made the recipe as noted except for the almonds as I have allergies. I agree that the sesame and poppy seeds give it a good texture. I also used "Craisins" as they were fast and easy to find at the grocery store. I simply put all the ingredients in a big bowl, whisked it with a fork and poured an appropriate amount over the quantity of spinach I already had. Wonderful!! Even my six year old ate it!! Thanks.

A keeper! I also toasted the almonds and sesames seeds together in a 350 degree oven & sprinkled on top.  Next time, I'll coat the spinach with the dressing and sprinkle everything else on top so that it doesn't fall to the bottom of the bowl.

I have made this salad twice in the past week for different groups. It was very well received both times.  I followed the recipe as written and I'm not inclined to change it. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a mega hit at my son's 3rd birthday party.  After reading a few reviews, I decided to leave out the poppy seeds too.  I was tempted to add a few things like gorgonzola cheese, pears or mandarin oranges but decided to keep it simple.  Some of my alterations included: one bag of baby spinach, one bag of mixed spring greens, canola oil, 1/2 bag of sliced almonds already toasted from Trader Joe's, craisins and pan toasted sesame seeds.  I also added 1/2 teaspoon salt and a few grinds of black pepper.  However, the real secret to this recipe is the amount of sugar.  I also make an insanely popular asian chicken salad that uses a similar amount of sugar in the dressing.   Personally, it's a little too sweet for me but it's so ridiculously requested, I can't stop making it!

text:
YUM YUM YUM!!!!
I happen to be browsing around on, and thought I'd check out the 'top 20' recipes overall, and this salad was in there.  With all the 5 star reviews, how could I not try it?!  I have to admit, I figured it would be good, but I thought the reviews were going a little overboard.....until my husband, myself, and our guests were all scraping as much as we possibly could out of the salad bowl!!!!!  Delicious!  I served it with some homemade beef stew and crusty bread, and I have to say that they went very well together.
I toasted the sesame seeds in a dry, non-stick skillet, and they went REALLY fast so you have to keep an eye on them.
I do think that next time I make this I will substitute Splenda for the sugar, since it is quite a bit of sugar.

Definitely worth a try everyone!!!

The first time I tried this I mixed all the dressing in with the salad, and felt it was too much (too soggy and was overwhelmed by the sweetness in the dressing). The second time I let each person mix the amount desired with the salad on his/her plate, and then discovered that the refrigerated leftover dressing is DELICIOUS served cold with cold pasta! (I used tricolor spiral pasta.) Next time I think I'll make extra dressing, just to have the leftovers to use in another pasta salad afterward...

text:
I can see why this is a 5-star recipe, it was incredible!  I did a few things differently:  I used splenda instead of sugar (couldn't tell the difference), I used a shallot instead of a onion because that's all I had, and I didn't toast the almonds (I felt lazy!).  The dressing is sweet but not too sweet, the cranberries add a nice bit of tartness to it, and with the spinach, it's an excellent source of fiber!  My only wish is that it would be lower in fat/calories.  I will definitely make this again, maybe I will try adding feta or blue cheese.

Loved it!  I followed the advice of others and toasted the almonds and sesame seeds in the oven for 10 minutes at 350 degrees.  Also cut down on the sugar to 1/4 cup, and used the Craisins (which are sweetened, so that balances out the sugar need).  Next time, I might throw in some bleu cheese.  This is a keeper!

This salad was delicious!!!  A good change from your normal green salad.  I also cut back on the sugar- used about 2 tbsp.  I also didnt use all of the dressing- it makes a little too much.  Toast the almonds and sesame seeds in a toaster oven and you can cut back on the butter.  This is a great salad to bring to a party or to pass- you will get alot of compliments.  Thanks for the recipe!

Yummy!  Made this for New Year's (served with prime rib) and for Easter (served with glazed ham).  Both times my mother-in-law stole the leftover dressing!  Made per the recipe, but will definitely try less sugar (or Splenda) and will try 1/2 the oil and sub olive in place of vegetable as others have suggested.  Definitely toast the almonds and sesame seeds in the oven (without butter).  Lends a nice woodsy flavor that compliments AND contrasts the other ingredients.

Hands down one of the best salads I've had..EVER! I served this at Thanksgiving and my guests requested seconds and thirds! I also used less oil, sugar, cider vingar, etc. You should def. toast the almonds in butter as it really brings out the flavor. Toasted seasme seeds were also a must for the dressing. Do not toss the salad with the dressing until the last minute in order to keep the spinach fresh. Thanks Jaime!

text:
I thought this salad was just ok.  I did change a few things though; I didn't toast the almonds in butter, in fact, I didn't toast them at all (toasting turns good fat into bad fat where nuts are concerned), instead of onion in the dressing, I used shallot and I omitted the poppy seeds because I didn't have any on hand.  Lastly, I used mixed greens instead of spinach.  In the end, we found the dressing to be a bit tangy for our liking, but our dinner guests did enjoy it.

text:
This salad was great.  Every time I make it, it disappears.  But, I don't add all of the dressing or it is too strong.  I keep about a 1/4 of it in the fridge and use it later in the week on a side salad.  Also, the lettuce gets really soggy if you let it sit.  So, I always toss the dressing in immediately before serving.

This was pretty good, though I expected nirvana from the other reviews!  To keep the cranberries from all slipping to the bottom, I only tossed half of them with the salad, dressed it and then sprinkled the other half on top. text:
This was a great salad!  I took other reviewers' advice and cut the sugar in half (and even then it was very sweet), I substituted pine nuts for the almonds (fantastic!), and did not add poppy seeds to the dressing.  It was sooo good!  I made for a dinner party and everyone raved and had seconds.  I really enjoyed the left-overs too, but be sure to add the dressing JUST before serving as is stated, otherwise, the spinach will be soggy (but still tasty).

Kudos Jamie!  I brought this to Easter dinner at my mom's, where our large family (about 38 people)loved it!  I doubled the recipe and added gorgonzola cheese, as some of the reviews suggested. My family is used to gourmet food, as my mother is a wonderful cook, so we will definitely have this salad again at our family gatherings, and I will make it again for dinner parties for friends.

I made this dressing tonight for a 100 person dinner and it received many compliments. The only differences in the dressing were I didnt use poppy seeds and i cut the sugar in half. It was still plenty sweet. When I trialled it last week with the planning committee, everyone said the dressing was just right for sweetness, and it was also suggested to leave out the poppy seeds. It is true, they dont really add anything to this salad. The salad itself was mixed greens, cranberries, toasted almonds, sunflower seeds, and a few slices of apple (tossed in lemon first).

userID:
16613276
Display Name:
Nicole
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Every time I make this recipe - it's a hit!  I even make it without some of the ingredients, if I am short some (sesame seeds, onion) and it still gets rave reviews.  Although, I think the sesame seeds & onion make it even that much better.  Some changes - I never saute the almonds- always lightly toast them in the toaster oven. I also use a mix of salad greens, instead of all spinach & I use Craisins as other reviewers have done as well.  If doubling the recipe - you do not need to double the dressing, as it makes plenty.  I've also thrown in some mandarin oranges for a splash of color or if I don't have Craisins on hand.  And if taking it to a party - I bring the dressing along & add it once we are ready to eat so it doesn't get soggy.  This is a great go to recipe- love it.

text:
I really loved this salad, although I bet I would like it better if I could find dried cranberries without sugar.  I always make a recipe the first time exactly as stated, but I just couldn't use 1/2 c. sugar in the dressing; yikes that a lot of sugar.  I used almost 1/4 cup and I thought it was delicious.  Those sesame seeds, yum!  And the toasted almonds, yum again.  I didn't use poppy seeds this time because I made it for company and people can be weird about having black seeds in their teeth, so I will add those in the leftover dressing.  I am sure it is the paprika and mixture of vinegars, but this dressing has a delicious, but unusual flavor that I loved.

I served this for 8 people and only used 7 oz. of spinach, but added all the same amounts of the rest.  I will have this again tonight!

text:
I roasted almonds and pecans on a sprayed cookie sheet- no butter.  Olive oil instead of veg oil and cut sugar by half.  This salad is outstanding!  I kept the dressing separate so the salad wouldn't get soggy.  Since making this for guests I now just make the dressing to keep in the fridge- I cut the sugar down to about a quarter of the original.  I make individual salads and just throw on some almonds/pecans or whatever nuts I have in the house and use whatever dried fruit- raisins, cranberries, plums.  I also add chopped red onion.  Easy and so good.

text:
I make the dressing the day before I need it. I frig it overnight that gives the ingred. a chance to marinate together. The sugar is way too much. You don't need to use all of the dressing you put it on the salad according to how much salad you have. When I have a large group I have them put their own dressing on that gives them the opportunity to use the amount that they want. I always have this dressing on hand just to use at my time on other types of salads. This salad does not save well if leftovers because of using the dressing on it.

text:
MMM, MMM    This is a very good recipe,  The dressing gives the spinach the perfect taste, the toasted nuts & seeds really top it off!  I did toast mine in a dry non-stick pan and it worked great.  After looking through a lot of the reviews, I think I will add some of the typical spinach salad ingredients next time, such as crumbled bacon & sliced eggs, the blue cheese looks interesting, but as it is, it's wonderful.  Everyone at our supper loved it!  It makes a large salad though & doesn't really keep well, the spinach totally wilts, so change the serving size to suit you.  I will be making this again & again, thank you for sharing this!!

This is a summertime favorite and so versatile. I was skeptical...this kind of salad isn't my thing. BUT, I loved it and apparently so did the rest of the families at the Ronald McDonald House where we served dinner.  The bowl went empty when all the other kinds of salads didn't!!  I will definitely be making again.  The only change I made to the recipe was to toast the nuts/seeds at 350 for 10min instead of using butter like other posters suggested.

country:
None
text:
I made this salad/dressing as is and gave it 4 stars. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because I felt the dressing called for too much sugar. So, I would recommend either half the sugar called for, or maybe a little over half, depending on your taste. I would also make the following slight adjustments:  Use shallots instead of minced white onion, blend the dressing ingredients together in a blender (except for sesame and poppy seeds), then add the sesame and poppy seeds to the salad, itself. With those adjustments, I would definitely make this dressing again!

Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! This was REALLY good!!! Since I was serving a hearty main dish (baked mostaccioli) and only three people, I halved this. To my surprise, not a DROP was left! I had to fight my mom for the last bit of salad lol! When my hubs is out of town, I like to make things I've always wanted to try but know he wouldn't care for (he's SOOOOO picky haha!!!). He is away on business this week, so I'm trying out a few new recipes! Having my parents around to keep me company is just an added bonus. :) As if this isn't PERFECT as is, I made a couple of (minor) changes. I added ~ 1/2 c. of crumbled blue cheese to my salad and subbed sliced almonds for slivers (all I had). Although delicious with the cheese (what's a salad without cheese??!!??!!?), I'm sure this would have been EXCELLENT without it. As a matter of fact, I'll probably leave it out next time. NOTE: DO toast your almonds in butter as directed! It makes a HUGE (and tasty!) difference!!! If you're concerned that your almonds will be greasy, set them on a paper towel-lined plate to soak up any excess butter. Toasting on high heat will also help (to absorb the butter), but you'll need to watch VERY carefully to avoid burning / scorching. Thanks SO much for sharing your recipe, Jamie. My dad requested that I serve this AGAIN (next weekend) for his Bday dinner! :-)

country:
None
text:
This salad was a complete hit.  I also threw in homemade croutons as I tossed it and the bowl it was served in was literally wiped clean.  For the croutons I bought I loaf of french bread ($1.00), cut it in cubes (I only used half the loaf) and tossed the cubes with 3 tbsp melted butter and 3 cloves of minced garlic.  When dinner was almost ready I threw them in the oven with the potatoes I was cooking on a separate cookie sheet for just a few minutes.  They were crunchy and soft and just about everyone had seconds (those who were quick enough!).  Easy and delish.

text:
Spectacular! I would give this 10 stars if I could. Fabulous tasting dressing. The only changes I made was to use balsamic vinegar in place of both cider and white and used olive oil instead of regular vegetable oil. I didn't have poppy seeds or sesame seeds, but did have sesame oil and threw some of that in. Even with the changes it still turned out delicious. I would love to try it with the poppy & sesame seeds as I'm sure it would make it that much better!

text:
Very tasty.  I made 1/2 recipe using 1 bag of prepackaged spinach and mixed lettuce for 6 people which was plenty and used only a small portion of the dressing (the dressing recipe is WAY too much for even a full recipe of salad).  Do not use butter when toasting the almonds!  I followed the recipe and did use butter which only made the almonds greasy and added calories.  I would have given it 5 stars except for the greasy almonds and tons of leftover dressing!  My guests liked it.

text:
Great recipe! I made it exactly as written, except for the fact that I was out of slivered almonds...so I used sliced ones instead. I was also out of white wine vinegar, so I used all cider vinegar instead. The combination of flavors was delicious, but I felt that either there was too much dressing, or the dressing was too sweet. Or maybe it was a combination of both. If I make this again, I'll definitely reduce the amount of sugar, and probably the amount of dressing as well. Thanks for sharing...this is a great, simple, and tasty salad!

This salad was easy and very tasty, but it wasn't transcendental or anything. And as per others' suggestions I used only 1/4 cup of sugar.  I will definitely make this again if I have spinach lying around.

text:
This recipe was so delicious, but there are a couple of things that I would like to mention.  I used the toasted and flavored almonds that are found in the salad aisle instead of toasting them myself.  I have 3 kids.  I don't toast nuts.  I also reduced the sugar as suggested in some reviews.  I only used 1/4 c.  Also, this made WAY more than 8 servings.  More like 20.  I would make this again in a heartbeat.  In fact, I served it at a ladies dinner, and have had several calls requesting the recipe.

text:
This is an amazing salad!! I have never, until having served this dish, seen people go back for seconds on salad. I halved the recipe my second time making it, not wanting any leftovers, and ended up running around in the kitchen because people were begging for more. I do think this serves more like 12 people. I served this for Thanksgiving and at a Christmas party, following the recipe exactly the first time and the second time leaving out the sesame seeds because I didn't have an- they were not missed. This is a very hard dish to mess up. It is super simple! You can really play with this. I added a large can of mandarin oranges. Highly recommended!! I'll make this again and again!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is by far the best salad I have ever made.  Ignore those who didn't like it, maybe they didn't follow the instructions?  I omitted the poppy seeds and almonds (as others suggested) and used toasted pine nuts and sesame seeds instead (without butter), added blue cheese and used Splenda instead of sugar.  Well lets just say that my husband and I basically ate this for dinner and left the chicken for the next nights leftovers.  I even ate the small leftover salad portion for breakfast the next day!  Will definitely make again, and again and again......

We love this salad and make it often.  I gave it four stars because:  1. You don't need the butter for the almonds, makes them greasy.  Dry toast them in a pan.  2.  Cut back on the sugar by half.  3.  Makes a lot of dressing, do not put the entire amount on.  Add gradually.

text:
I love, love, love this recipe and have used it for years.  I recommend cutting the sugar in half.  I use it pretty much as is in the fall and winter.  In the spring and summer I switch out the cranberries for fresh berries and mandarin oranges (I have also used fresh pineapple),switch out the almonds for pecans, and romaine and spring mix for the spinach (don't forget to keep the sesame seeds).  It is fantastic!  You can make the dressing and toast the nuts and seeds the day before.

text:
YUM!  Everybody always loves this salad!  Do not add the dressing until just ready to serve because it tends to wilt the spinach.  Also, this recipe makes a huge batch.  I cut everything in half and toss it with a 9 oz bag of baby spinach.  I also replace half the veg oil with olive oil.  I omit the poppy seeds and add sesame sticks and crumbled blue cheese.  Oh, and I use 1/8 teaspoon onion powder instead of the minced fresh onion. :)

text:
GREAT salad!  I served this with Sensational Sirloin Kabobs and Gourmet Mushroom Risotto all from this site.  I did use 1/4 c. sugar but would cut it down to 1 or 2 T. when I make again.  Used peanut oil as well.  I didn't add the cheese to it but it would be good with a chevre, blue or any other kind of crumbled cheese you may like.  The toasted almonds really add a lot and I did them on a sheet pan in the oven with no butter.  Next time, I'm going to use field greens or baby lettuce.  This is a keeper!

text:
Tasty salad!  Easy prep...I bought packaged spinach, slivered almonds, and craisins, so all that was left to do was make the dressing.  I subbed balsamic vinegar for the white wine vinegar, garlic powder for the minced onion, and brown sugar for the white.  My fiance still thought it was a bit on the tart side, so I'm going to tweak the dressing to his liking, but overall great mix of flavors.  I can't wait to try it with some protein (grilled chicken breast or even some tuna)!

This is an absolutely delicious salad. However, for 'healthier' eating tips i wouldn't suggest frying the almonds in butter, instead  i placed almonds in the salad without frying and it is just as delicious. The sugar recommendation in the recipe also was a little much, i found that 1/4 cup or no sugar at all is just as good. Otherwise, its fast and so tastey!

text:
After reading many reviews about this salad i made it last night. I tweaked a few things. I didnt use poppy seeds, i cut the oil and sugar in half, and i added mandarin oranges to it. Oh and instead of using all spinach i used spinach and mixed greens. It was delicious!!!! I think the mandarin oranges are a must, they go so well with the dressing. This was a wonderful salad. The flavors go so well together. I will most definitely make this again. I have a BBQ to attend in a few weeks and i know it will be a hit. Of course to avoid the lettuce getting soggy but dressing on right before serving.

text:
Made this for Thanksgiving and it was a huge hit!  Cheated a little and bought baby spinach leaves in a bag.  I plated the salads in advance, adding only the almonds and cranberries.  Just before serving, I dressed them.  It makes for a great presentation . . . so colorful.  Just a caution, don't cook the almonds too long or they'll taste bitter.  I used the slivered almonds and had to make a second batch.  Glad I did.  Thanks for sharing, Jamie!  This was a great way to add green amongst all of the starches.
