None
text:
This is a wonderfully delicious salad. My wife and I made this for some friends, and the salad went quickly. The dressing was out of this world. I've made this dressing for other salads, as a marinade, mix in with noodles, etc. It's one of my favorites. The sweet of the sugar and the sour of the vinegar add a pleasant change to any salad. One thing, don't let the salad dressing sit for too long, as the vinegar will overpower the sugar and ytou lose that balance. All in all, my family loved this salad and dressing, and I will definitely make it again. For a added flavor, add bluecheese crumbles.

i made this salad for a staff lunch, and EVERYONE wanted the recipe afterwards!  i used the advice from other reviewers to use only half the sugar--worked out great.  also, you can substitute 1/4-1/2 teaspoon of onion powder if you don't feel like mincing onions.

text:
Like many others, we had this with our Easter ham yesterday and it was just great. My husband kept dipping his ham into the leftover dressing on his plate! The toasted sesame seeds really give the dressing's flavor a punch. Toasting both the sesame seeds and the almonds are definitely a must. Suggestion if you have leftovers...don't dress the salad. Have people dress their own portions, then you won't have a problem with soggy leftover salad the next day. Thanks, Jamie!

Updating my review - we added some battered and fried chicken breast chunks. We poured some of the dressing directly on the chicken and put it in the salad. OH MY GOSH!!! It was so awesome. We just kept saying, man we're good!

I made this for my husband and he now thinks I'm a great cook. It's just like our favorite salad at our favorite restaurant. Then I made it for my mom's birthday party, and I am still getting compliments. I used distilled white vinegar and apple cider vinegar the first time. The second time, I halfed the white and added some balsamic - much sweeter. I think I liked it better. It's now in my repertoire as well as my mom's and her best friend.

text:
This is the most delicious salad I have ever had - period. It was also so easy to do - mix up the dressing beforehand and just add to the salad right before serving. I considered adding less sugar but didn't after reading the other reviews - they were right, too - don't change a thing! I used the washed baby spinach so I didn't even have to tear the leaves! Oh, I couldn't find white wine vinegar so used regular white and it was just delicious! You would be crazy to not at least try this recipe!!! YUM!!

text:
I like dressings in the background. Let the salad ingredients shine. I squeezed half of a lemon into salad bowl. Added thinly sliced onion to the juice (the acid sweetens it). Pour in a little olive oil, small amount of sugar, paprika. Stir to dissolve sugar. Thats it. 

Toasted almonds in butter, toasted sesame seeds, softened cranberries, avocado, mango, anything goes.

text:
I am addicted to this spinach salad!  It's very healthy and tasty.  I don't change a thing in the recipe other than cutting the sugar by half.  You can buy the dried cranberries with 50% less sugar than regular, because they do contain alot of sugar.  I like to keep the toasted almonds in a small container and use them at the time I eat the salad rather than mixing them into the spinach, because they can get a little soggy otherwise.  The dressing is so delicious.  I make it about every other week and sometimes two batches per week.  Soooo good!

userID:

Display Name:
cltncook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good!  I adjusted the servings to 2 and while I added some additional ingredients to finish up some items from the fridge, I still made the basic salad--just with some extras.  My salad greens were a mixture of spinach and baby greens.  I used a handful of whole, natural almonds, subbed dried cherries for cranberries, a handful of sunflower seeds for the sesame and poppy seeds, and in the dressing , subbed a bit of onion powder for the onion.  To the salad, I added a  chopped nectarine, a thinly sliced radish, some red onion,  1 chopped celery stick,  a few leftover black olives, a small piece of cheese cut up, and a leftover baked chicken thigh cut up with the skin removed.  I sprinkled some seasoning salt on the piece of chicken skin and microwaved it on a paper-lined plate for about 1-1/2 minutes to make chicken cracklins, and then crumbled it into the salad.  It made a great tasting, big salad for lunch.  May reduce the sugar a bit next time.
Review:

5

I have made this salad many of times now and I will admit its one of the best salads out there. text:
Took a chance on this one, because I happened to have all the ingredients. Well, it was a huge success!  Everyone really liked the unusual flavor of the dressing, and paired with the salad, it was perfect. People even asked to take some of the leftover home with them.  That doesn't usually happen with green salad.  Be sure to make the dressing in enough time for the flavors to develop well.  I noticed when I first made it, it tasted quite vinegary. But after a couple hours, the flavors developed into a great tasting dressing!  I'll make it again, since it is quite easy and delicious.

text:
My "go to" recipe when I'm asked to bring a salad! Everybody always raves and asks me for the recipe...super easy to make ahead too! Mix the spinach, dried cranberries and cooled toasted almonds together and place in container. Then mix the dressing ingredients and place in Tupperware and refrigerate until ready to serve!  Easy peasy and didn't change a  thing!

This salad dressing was AMAZING. I used half the amount of cider vinegar( I used apple cider with the mother) and half the amount of sugar. It was the perfect amount of vinegar and sweetness for me, anymore sugar and I think it'd be too sweet personally. I didn't do anything to my almonds, just used sliced ones. Seriously the best dressing I've ever had in my life. I even made this for my dad who is NOT a greens or salad eater, and he went back for seconds and said "this now has to be a staple food in our house". Love it!

text:
Everyone loved this and asked for the recipe.  The two things that I would do differently next time:  1) There is too much dressing made.  I would probably 1/2 the amount of dressing so it was a little lighter.  2) I would probably add it to each salad separately because the next day it wilts the spinach.  However, it also could have been a result of #1.

Loved it!!!  I will make this again!!!

text:
I would have rated this a 5 star if the dressing was not so tangy (too much vinegar).  I made the initial version and found it too vinegary.  I cut back on the vinegar and increased the oil, so my ratio was 3 parts oil to 1 part vinegar.  Since the total liquid amount was 1 cup, I used 3/4 c olive oil and 1/8 cup of each of the vinegars listed.  I also cut back on the sugar.  I loved all the other ingredients used, especially the seeds.  Thanks!

text:
Awesome recipe!!  Have made this LOTS. The only change I've made was to cut the oil and the sugar to 1/4 cup each.  To the salad I will julienne a red or yellow pepper, add some sunflower seeds, and sometimes I'll section a mandarin orange just to add some colour.  I will also double the recipe and keep remainder of dressing in a mason jar in the fridge.  Will keep for about 3 weeks.  Thank you for sharing!!

text:
As the recipe is written, I rate this salad 4 stars.  It is a delicious salad, although a bit sweet for my family's tastes, as well as a little heavy on the oil.

The second time I made it, I reduced the sugar by half but still felt it was too sweet.  I also cut the oil in half.  Next time, I will cut the sugar back to 3 Tbsp, as well as further reduce the oil.  With these changes, it should get a 5-star rating in my book.

Jamie, thanks for the recipe!  It's not a combination of ingredients I would have ever thought to use together.

text:
This was a super salad for my luncheon that I had with a few girlfriends.  Everyone loved it, it was fresh and light.  I served it with some warm garlic bread sticks and everyone enjoyed it.  All 4 of my girlfriends wanted the recipe, which I graciously shared with them.  I always have craisins in my house, along with almonds, but never thought to put the two together.  I might try adding some bacon to the salad for a protein, as I think it would be a great fit.  My girlfriend also suggested using the bacon grease in place of the oil for added flavor.  I will definitely try her suggestions, but I do plan to make this salad for Thanksgiving.  I think it will be a great salad that is light and fresh and wont take focus away from the Turkey, stuffing and all the other wonderful dishes.  Great recipe.  It is definitely a keeper!

text:
I've made this salad multiple times since I discovered it a few months ago.  It's a great side salad for potluck dinners or parties because EVERYONE LOVES IT!!  Sesame seeds are expensive though, so I don't always include them- but the other flavors are great and no one ever seems to miss the sesame seeds.  Some comments mention this recipe being time consuming, but it's really not... toasting the almonds takes a few minutes, but other than that it's pretty quick.  And worth it!

text:
This was a fabulous salad.  I made the dressing ahead and took it and the spinach and almonds to the party and assembled it there. Judging by the above reviews I guessed it was going to be a hit so I brought extra.  And yep, I  had to keep refilling the salad bowl because everyone loved it so much.  Light, refreshing and TASTY!  And sooooooo simple!
I, too, cut the sugar down to a couple of tablespoons and pan toasted the nuts with no butter.  But there is a lot of flexibility room here, so you can play with the ingredients.  Nobody's looking. Make it your own.  But just so you know.........its fantastic as is.
Thanks for submitting........its going to the 4th of July party in duplicate!
Lori in Florida

text:
I've been making this recipe for YEARS and everyone LOVES it. I (like many others) cut the sugar to 1/4 c. and use extra virgin olive oil instead of veg. oil. I also use brown sugar, instead of white - just seems to be a bit more flavorful. My former inlaws would argue over who got any leftover after family dinners. Thank you, Jamie - this one's a winner!

userID:
11098658
Display Name:
Melissa Hinshaw-Owens
isPro:

followersCount:
6
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3135505.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this Sunday with a meatloaf and mashed potato meal. Very good! I read a lot of the reviews...mostly too sweet and too tangy. I used half the sugar, rice wine vinegar because it's more mild than apple cidar vinegar, and unsweetened cranberries. I also used olive oil. I minced a half of a small  sweet vidalia onion (Flat, round disk-like onions are the sweetest) MAKE SURE that your olive oil is not rancid or spoiled. This can ruin your recipe. Taste it BEFORE you put it on the salad. I layered the spinach, toasted nuts, cranberries then sprinkled the dressing layering as I went. I found it to be a great way to assemble this beautiful salad. Fresh ingredients assure the best results. Bon Apetite!

text:
This was so good   My husband loved it. I had to make  substitution for white wine vinegar as I had none in the house so I used 2 Tbsp balsamic vinegar and 2 Tbsp white vinegar plus1 Tbsp of reduced sodium soya sauce. I cut back on the sugar, only 1/3 c and it was still a bit too sweet for my liking so I would cut back to 1/4 c next time or try some Mirin as it is readily mixable with the other wet ingredients. Thanks for sharing this recipe.

I have never been a big salad eater, but after reading the reviews I figured I would give it a try. I ended up tossing most of it.  I am not sure if having white wine vinegar makes a different, but I did not have it on hand and used regular vinegar instead.  However, the little I did not toss was used to make a sandwich with a little bit of leftover chicken salad and it sort of reminded of I think similar sandwich that Wendy's or Arby's have. In the future I would probably make a small amount of dressing and a small amount of salad for a sandwich, the chicken and bread seemed to get rid of the vinegary taste and made it okay.

text:
I enjoyed this but like others I thought the dressing was too sweet and there was too much of it. Next time I would cut the dressing in half and use only half the sugar. Still, it was enjoyed by my Thanksgiving crowd and the red and green colors were festive for the holidays. I added some pomegranate seeds and red onion and they really made the colors pop. I also added sugar coated pecans instead of the almonds, and tossed in some feta, which was a nice salty balance to the sweet dressing.

text:
Even after cutting the sugar in half, this was WAY too sweet.  I didn't like it, but I'm giving it four stars due to the number of compliments I received on it.  Once I got home with the leftovers, I put feta cheese in it, which cut the sweetness and added a bit of sour/tart taste to it.  Much better with it!  I would have liked to put in goat cheese like others suggested, but didn't have any.  So, if you are concerned about the sweet, add in some feta or goat cheese!  It makes a huge difference!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good - your basic bistro spinach salad. I used dried cherries instead of cranberries (had one, not the other) and skipped the onion because I'm lazy. I also used half the sugar in the dressing and half the oil; the dressing is nice, tangy with a tiny little bite at the end from the paprika. Can't imagine it with the full amount of sugar, though. I also only used 6 ounces of spinach (so slightly less than half called for) and used far less than half the dressing. So four stars because I can't imagine all that sugar in the dressing, and I also can't imagine using all that dressing - plus some, with the extra oil and sugar! - on a salad.

text:
This was a good recipe, though I feel like I've eaten it before. The poppy seeds added a strange crunch, and the balsamic did not taste good with the spinach. It tasted sort of bitter. Instead, I used olive and regular vinegar. Another thing I didn't love about this was using only spinach. Instead, I used mixed baby greens, with spinach added. It gives a nice balance. Generally, though, this is really tasty. I also tried replaces the almonds with walnuts, and it worked great.

This is a must try! I did do a couple of things differenty. When mixing up the dressing ahead of time I grated the onion for a smoother texture, and cut the oil in half. I then added the cranberries and let marinate for about an hour wisking a few times. Lastly, when tossing the salad; I added crumbled reduced fat feta. I loved this salad so much I might have it again tonight!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/175928.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum - such an easy delicious salad.  I made this for an Inaguration party and it was definitely a hit.  My adjustments - I used Craisins and toasted Macadamia nuts (my nod to Hawaii) in addition to the sliced almonds and sesame seeds.  To travel to the party, I kept the craisins/nuts in one container, and the dressing in another, and then dumped them all together with the baby spinach moments before serving.  I would recommend eating this within a day - otherwise the dressing settles and the lettuce becomes a bit drowned.  However - this was such a yummy dish that you may not need to worry about leftovers!

text:
I just brought this salad to Thanksgiving and everyone really liked it - even the people who don't like spinach.  The only changes I made were to toast the dry sliced almonds at 350 degrees in the oven for 10 minutes and I added a 1/2 cup of gorgonzola cheese.  Several reviewers said that the dressing was too sweet, but my family thought it was perfect.  Guess it just depends on what youre looking for.  I will definitely make this again.

None
country:
None
text:
This was really good.  I was looking for a recipe to use up a pomegranate.  I made a few modifications based on what I had on hand.  I used shallots in place of onions in the viniagrette.  I cooked pecans in sugar and let them cool, chopped them and used in place of almonds.  I used granny smith apples for crunch and half of a pomegranate...squeezing the juice over the salad and picking out the fruit.  Instead of spinach, I used romaine.  I had some gorgonzola cheese crumbles to throw in, but they had spoiled, so I omitted cheese altogether.  My husband swears by ranch and he really like this salad.

Add me to the list of lovers of this recipe!!

 I followed the recipe pretty close. I used pecans instead of almonds and glazed them with
butter and maple syrup instead of just butter. I also used a quarter cup of sugar instead of the recommned 1/2 cup. Still a tad sweet for us so the next night I added 1 tablespoon less sugar and added some strawberries. Wow, we love it! A new favorite in our family. 
I should also add that when my husband saw the spinach salad he curled his nose up at it, but everyone was raving so he decided to try. We have a new spinach convert, THANK - YOU!!

This one is great!  To cut down on fat and sugar, I dry toast the almonds in the oven and use 1/4 cup of Splenda instead of sugar.  I also prefer dried cherries instead of cranberries.  The recipe makes more dressing than I use, so I use the extra throughout the week on my lunch salads.  With sliced grilled chicken breast on top, this is a super meal!

text:
Excellent salad. I have made this other very similiar salad for a few years using straberries instead of cranberries. Good either way. Never have much left. Toasting the almonds is very good. Don't leave that part out. I also toasted the sesame seeds (it calls for it but doesn't tell you to do it). Great salad, if you are looking for a "magazine" type salad to impress, use this one.

text:
Wow. I must say that I didn't expect to like this all that much, but it is really fabulous! I did just use a bag of baby spinach leaves to make things easier, and doubled the recipe, as I used it at a dinner series I'm catering, but other than that followed the recipe as written. I don't know why I'm not more adventurous on my own. I would never make a salad with nuts or berries in it at home because it doesn't sound great to me, but I did make this thinking others would enjoy it and I fell in love with it too! The dressing was pretty sweet, and I mentioned cutting down on the sugar next time to one of the guests, but he thought it was great. So I'll probably just leave it as is. I'm so glad I tried this!!!

I made this today for a potluck and got rave reviews! Quite a few have asked for the recipe. I made minor changes, but not many! I used (2) 9 oz. bags of ready to go baby spinach, red wine vinegar, and 1/4c light olive oil, and 1/4c vegetable oil, & about 1/8th t. salt to taste. I made the dressing ahead of time for the flavors to blend. YUMMY! Thanks Jamie!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674139.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This salad gets raves everytime I serve it. To save time, I mix the dressing ingred. the night before a party, toast the nuts in the microwave and reserve for the next day.    I half the sugar as suggested (too sweet otherwise) and add halfed cherry tomatoes and feta cheese.  I use raspberry vinegar instead of the white wine vinegar.  I toss everything together at the last minute.  Presto, instant addition to any party! This salad is a soggy mess the next day, so leftovers are not recommended.  Mix only as much as you will eat in any given dinner.  It looks and tastes fancy smancy but no one needs to know just how simple it is!  All Recipes Rocks!
